You hold in your hand a machine of incredible complexity. A machine that can record things about the world surrounding you, in details more meticulous than you could ever perceive, and then consider and translate them in the flip of a bit into forms that would take you hours to recreate. If this machine can think, can it create?

This app has been designed to take information it collects from the world around it and use it to create works of art, inspired by pioneering computer artists of the 60s such as Hiroshi Kawano and Harold Cohen. These artists looked at art as a logical activity, concerned more with the algorithmic procedure of drawing and the mathematics of geometry than with freedom of expression (1). Harold Cohen and the program he designed, AARON, could create hugely complex abstract drawings, led by algorithms designed by Cohen to increase AARON’s knowledge of composition and colour (2).

Other important artistic movements that have influenced this app such as Fluxus, and Aleatory musicians, have adopted algorithmic practices and used elements of random chance in their creative processes. This has helped them to find ways to create things not bound by decision making, and transfer some of the creative responsibility from the artist to the spectator (3).
